There's an interesting thing about video
game adaptations Whether you want to
adapt it closely to the original video
game or be given free reign to do
whatever you want but still stay
faithful Onetoone
adaptation moments can be great So in
something like The Last of Us when you
look at the opening that's a classic
example of one:1 where you're seeing
truly the actual cinematography that
happened within the game during those
cut scenes mirrored on set And that's
really cool That's amazing to see But
that's also a show that expanded and had
a whole episode about characters that
don't exist in in the games at all And
and it was you know one of the most
successful episodes of that show And
everybody fell in love with you know
adorable farmer Nick Offerman So I think
sometimes it's that balance of of being
able to expand and pull back You can be
like a nitpicky gamer where you be like
"Oh Joel's holding the gun this way."
And how he reacts to the gun in a video
game is different than how Pedro Pascal
as him reacts in the uh show And again
onetoone adaptations of anything don't
really work for us Look at The Lion King
experiment right that did well at the
box office It it pleased plenty of
people who needed to get to the theaters
to take their kids to go see something
but it didn't necessarily make this
lasting connection It didn't explore the
material to the same breath And I think
that's a big part of it is being able to
pay homage but also expand and own
something without betraying it
I think if I had to give advice to a
director who was approaching a video

I think you shouldn't necessarily just
